captions.text: My favorite champion is Nidalee.
“On the prowl.”
There are many builds for Nidalee. In tournaments, I like to play Nidalee as a bruiser.
The most important thing for this build is giving the enemy initiator some pressure
while at the same time disrupting enemy's carries so they can't do as much damage to yours.
Using pounce while in cougar form increases the champion's overall flexibility.
When you are using pounce, sometimes you can change back to the human form before you hit the ground.
You can master this trick, and when you do, it feels really good.
There was this one time when I had Frozen Mallet and was attacking an enemy champion.
The passive on Frozen Mallet went off, and the enemy was slowed.
I took advantage of the bushes to get closer, and then I changed into cougar form and used Takedown on him.
He died before he was able to use his ultimate, and that was an awesome moment.
“Here mousie mousie mousie.”
Maybe the reason I like playing Nidalee the most
is because I usually like champions who can split push, or remain difficult to gank by enemy junglers.
You not only need to be familiar with the champion and basic micromanagement techniques,
but you also need the right strategy because when playing Nidalee, the most important thing is split-pushing.
When you split push, you have to the pay attention to the mini-map all the time.
The position of enemy champions, where you should place wards, when you need to split-push, and when you need to group for teamfights.
These are all things you need to understand, and have experience doing.
I am June Tsan “Stanley” Wang.
I play with the Taipei Assassins.
My favorite champion is Nidalee.

title: Pro Player Pick: Stanley Picks Nidalee
